Question Text: In a spoofing attack, which of the following parameters are commonly spoofed? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Source IP address
b. MAC address
c. ARP address
d. Routing table
e. Destination IP address
f. ARP table
LLM Explanation: In a spoofing attack, the attacker typically falsifies or 'spoofs' the source IP address and/or the MAC address. By spoofing the source IP, the attacker can hide their true identity and location. Spoofing the MAC address allows the attacker to impersonate another device on the local network. The other choices - ARP address, routing table, destination IP, and ARP table - are not commonly spoofed in these types of attacks.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 6: Fundamentals of IP Security', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-spoofing.html']

Question Text: AAA servers usually support the protocol TACACS+ and ____________________ to communicate with enterprise resources.
Choices:
a. DHCP
b. ARP
c. RADIUS
d. HTTP
LLM Explanation: AAA servers typically support the RADIUS (Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service) protocol in addition to TACACS+ for communicating with enterprise resources. RADIUS is a widely used protocol for centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, 2020', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/sec_usr_aaa/configuration/15-mt/sec-usr-aaa-15-mt-book/sec-cfg-radius.html']

Question Text:
The senior network engineer assigns you a task related to port security. He needs your help to configure the fa0/1 from the SW-examsD to accept frames only from the MAC 0200.1111.2222.
Type the commands that need to be configured on the SW-examsD following the requirements below:
1. configure the FastEthernet0/1 to be an access port
2. enable port security on that interface
3. define the allowed MAC address
Choices:
a. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/2
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.1111.2222
b. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
c. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.2222.2222
d. SW-examsD#configure terminal
SW-examsD(config)#interface FastEthernet0/1
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport mode access
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security
SW-examsD(config-if)#switchport port-security macaddress 0200.1111.2222
LLM Explanation: Option d is the correct configuration to meet the given requirements. It configures interface FastEthernet0/1 as an access port, enables port security on that interface, and defines the allowed MAC address as 0200.1111.2222. Option a configures the wrong interface (fa0/2 instead of fa0/1). Option b enables port security but does not define the allowed MAC address. Option c defines the wrong MAC address (0200.2222.2222 instead of 0200.1111.2222).
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 11: Implementing Ethernet Virtual LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst2960/software/release/15-2_2_e/configuration/guide/b_1522e_2960_2960c_2960s_2960sf_2960p_cg/b_1522e_2960_2960c_2960s_2960sf_2960p_cg_chapter_01001.html']

Question Text: _____________________ attacks typically function by overwhelming or flooding a targeted machine with requests until normal traffic is unable to be processed, resulting in denial- of-service to additional users.
Choices:
a. Spoofing
b. Phishing
c. DoS
d. SQL injection
LLM Explanation: Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks aim to make a system or network resource unavailable to its intended users by overwhelming the target with a flood of traffic or requests. The attack consumes the target's available bandwidth or resources, preventing it from processing legitimate requests. This matches the description provided in the question.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 14: Security Architectures', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-a-ddos-attack.html']

Question Text: A _________________ is malicious software that is hidden and packaged inside other software that looks normal and legitimate.
Choices:
a. Worm
b. Virus
c. Spyware
d. Trojan
LLM Explanation: A Trojan is a type of malicious software (malware) that is disguised as legitimate software. It is designed to trick users into installing and executing it on their systems. Once activated, a Trojan can enable unauthorized access to the system, allowing the attacker to steal sensitive data, install additional malware, modify files, monitor user activity, or use the compromised machine for other malicious activities. Unlike viruses and worms, Trojans do not typically self-replicate.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press, 2020', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/advanced-malware-protection/what-is-malware.html', 'https://www.malwarebytes.com/trojan/']

Question Text: What devices can be used to implement DHCP Snooping? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Hub
b. Layer 2 switches
c. Routers
d. Layer 3 switches
e. Access Points
f. End users
LLM Explanation: DHCP snooping is a security feature that can be implemented on Layer 2 switches and Layer 3 switches. It helps prevent unauthorized DHCP servers from assigning IP addresses to clients and mitigates DHCP starvation attacks. Routers, hubs, access points, and end-user devices cannot implement DHCP snooping as it is a switch-specific feature.
URLs: ['Cisco Press CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 9: DHCP Snooping', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst3750x_3560x/software/release/12-2_55_se/configuration/guide/3750xscg/swdhcp82.html']

Question Text: Which of the following Cisco Firepower NGIPS’s features provides more insights into and control over the users, applications, devices, threats, and vulnerabilities in your network with real-time visibility?
Choices:
a. Security automation
b. Granular application visibility and control
c. Contextual awareness
d. Superior effectiveness
LLM Explanation: Contextual awareness provides more insights into and control over the users, applications, devices, threats, and vulnerabilities in the network with real-time visibility. It allows the Cisco Firepower NGIPS to understand the context of network traffic, including user identity, device type, application, and potential threats, enabling more granular security policies and better threat detection.
URLs: ['Cisco Firepower Next-Generation IPS (NGIPS) Data Sheet: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/security/firepower-ngips/datasheet-c78-736775.html', 'Cisco Firepower NGIPS Features and Capabilities: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/firepower-ngips/features.html']

Question Text: What can be accomplished with a brute-force attack?
Choices:
a. Guess a user’s password
b. Make a server unavailable
c. Spoof every possible IP address
d. Alter a routing table
LLM Explanation: A brute-force attack involves systematically trying every possible password combination to gain unauthorized access to a user account. It attempts to 'guess' the correct password by exhaustively trying all possibilities. The other choices are not directly related to brute-force attacks. Making a server unavailable would be a denial-of-service attack, spoofing IP addresses is a separate technique, and altering routing tables is not a goal of brute-force password guessing.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 5: Security Fundamentals', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/what-is-a-brute-force-attack.html']

Question Text: Social engineering attack is accomplished through human interactions. It uses psychological manipulation to trick users into making security mistakes or giving away sensitive information.
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. Social engineering attacks rely on human interaction and manipulating people into breaking normal security procedures, such as revealing sensitive information or granting unauthorized access. These attacks exploit human psychology rather than technical hacking techniques.
URLs: ['NIST Special Publication 800-63B Digital Identity Guidelines: Authentication and Lifecycle Management', 'SANS Institute: Social Engineering Attacks: Common Techniques & How to Prevent an Attack', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Cybersecurity']

Question Text: Which of the following human security vulnerabilities attacks is a type of attack that targets high-profile employees, such as the CEO or CFO, in order to steal sensitive information from a company?
Choices:
a. Social engineering
b. Phishing
c. Whaling
d. Pharming
LLM Explanation: Whaling is a type of phishing attack that specifically targets high-profile employees, such as CEOs, CFOs, or other executives, in order to steal sensitive information from a company. The attackers craft highly personalized emails or messages to trick these high-value targets into revealing confidential data, transferring funds, or granting access to restricted systems.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2020)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/email-security/what-is-phishing.html', 'https://www.kaspersky.com/resource-center/definitions/spear-phishing']

Question Text: Which of the following human security vulnerabilities attacks is the attempt to obtain sensitive information such as passwords and credit card details by disguising oneself as a trustworthy entity?
Choices:
a. Social engineering
b. Phishing
c. Whaling
d. Pharming
LLM Explanation: Phishing is a type of social engineering attack where the attacker attempts to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information such as passwords or credit card details by disguising themselves as a trustworthy entity, often via email. The attacker may impersonate a legitimate company, bank, or even a colleague to gain the victim's trust and manipulate them into disclosing confidential data.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press, 2020', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/email-security/what-is-phishing.html', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/articles/what-is-phishing']

Question Text: Which of the following security features rejects invalid and malicious ARP packets and prevents a class of man-in-the-middle attacks?
Choices:
a. DoS
b. DAI
c. Packet secure
d. ARP protect
LLM Explanation: Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) is a security feature that validates ARP packets in a network and discards ARP packets with invalid IP-to-MAC address bindings. This helps prevent certain man-in-the-middle attacks, such as ARP cache poisoning, by not relaying invalid or malicious ARP replies out to other ports in the same VLAN. DAI relies on the DHCP snooping binding database to verify IP-to-MAC bindings.
URLs: ['Cisco Press CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 15: IP Services', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12-2SX/configuration/guide/book/snoodhcp.html']

Question Text: In a reflection attack, the source IP address in the attack packets is spoofed so that it contains the address of the victim.
LLM Explanation: In a reflection attack, the attacker spoofs the source IP address of the packets they send, replacing it with the IP address of the intended victim. When the recipient of these spoofed packets (the reflector) responds, the replies are sent to the victim's IP address rather than back to the attacker. This allows the attacker to hide their identity and amplify the attack traffic directed at the victim.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 7: IP Version 4 Addressing', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ddos/glossary/ip-spoofing/', 'https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/reflection-attack/']

Question Text: Type the command that needs to be configured on a switch to automatically recover from the err-disabled state, when caused by port security.
Choices:
a. recovery cause psecure-violation
b. errdisable recovery psecure-violation
c. errdisable recovery
d. errdisable recovery cause psecure-violation
LLM Explanation: To automatically recover from the err-disabled state caused by port security violations, the correct command is 'errdisable recovery cause psecure-violation'. This command enables the switch to automatically re-enable the port after a specified time interval when it has been disabled due to a port security violation.
URLs: ['Cisco Networking Academy, CCNA Routing and Switching: Switched Networks v5.0, Chapter 2: Basic Switch Configuration', 'Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference, Release 12.2, errdisable recovery']

Question Text: A next-generation firewall sits at the edge of a company’s connection to the Internet. A network engineer has been configured to prevent Telnet clients residing on the Internet from accessing Telnet servers inside the company. Which of the following might a next-generation firewall use that a traditional firewall would not?
Choices:
a. Match message destination well-known port 23
b. Match message application data
c. Match message IP protocol 23
d. Match message source TCP ports lower than 5400
LLM Explanation: A next-generation firewall, unlike a traditional firewall, can inspect the application layer data of network traffic to identify the specific application or service being used. In this case, it could identify Telnet traffic by analyzing the application data, rather than just relying on port numbers or IP protocols which can be easily changed or spoofed. Traditional firewalls typically only operate up to layer 4 (transport layer) of the OSI model.
URLs: ['Cisco Press CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 7: Security Architectures', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/security/firewalls/what-is-a-next-generation-firewall.html']

Question Text: Your PC connects to a LAN and uses DHCP to lease an IP address for the first time. Of the usual four DHCP messages that flow between the PC (DHCP client) and the DHCP server, which ones do the server send? (Choose two answers)
Choices:
a. Acknowledgment
b. Request
c. Offer
d. Discover
LLM Explanation: In the DHCP process, the server sends two of the four messages: DHCPOFFER and DHCPACK. The DHCPOFFER message is sent in response to the client's DHCPDISCOVER message, offering an IP address and other configuration parameters. If the client accepts the offer, it sends a DHCPREQUEST message. The server then responds with a DHCPACK (acknowledgment) to confirm the lease and provide the client with the finalized configuration.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 17: IP Routing in the LAN', 'RFC 2131: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol']
